item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
The first time I played 7 Wonders, I immediately knew it was a keeper. It's a lot of fun to see how your little empire builds up over the course of a game, and I love how there is no down time.
I also own the Leaders expansion (highly recommended for when 7 Wonders starts to feel "samey"), the Wonders Pack, and the Catan Island promo.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment: 7 Wonders was starting to feel a bit stale, and Leaders fixed that problem right up!

item.name: A la carte
item.comment: Fun, fast, silly game. I love the pictures of the food (my personal favorite: post modern coffee, which is just a puddle of water and a few beans), love the awesome components (recommendation: use super glue to keep the bottoms of the shakers on), and love how much everyone constantly messes up during the game. If only I was better at flipping crepes...
item.wishlistcomment: Definitely looks like nothing else I've got in my collection, and also looks like a fun game to play with the future kids.

item.name: Abyss
item.comment:
Not a bad game at all, but feels very overproduced compared to the gameplay. I find myself wanting to own the game despite a very lukewarm experience with it so far, and that is pretty much completely due to the artwork and component quality.
Beautiful game, but not worth owning just to look at.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Great, great game. You never feel like you have enough turns to get everything you need, and the tension that can build up is amazing. Probably the best designed game I've ever played, although not necessarily the most fun. I highly recommend upgrading your copy with some veggie/resource/animeeples!
I also own the Gamers' Deck expansion.
UPDATE: Unfortunately, it looks like Agricola has been fired from my collection by Caverna. The tension I love in Agricola is largely absent from Caverna, which is a big plus for my wife and other members of my game group.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: Nice and relaxing. I'm pretty sure we play by the wrong rules and make the game much more luck dependent, but I still have a lot of fun with this one.

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment:
Fun, thematic game. The core set is good for awhile, but after a few games you'll start picking up on cards that are kind of stinky and wishing you could streamline your strategy a bit more.
Even if you aren't interested in expansions or building you own decks, I'd definitely still say this one is worth buying.
I own 2 core sets and all of the Genesis Cycle and Spin Cycle. I think my collecting days are over, however. I only really play this game with one friend, and it's not worth the constant investment to keep up with the new releases. I've got enough cards to last me forever.

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Anyone can have fun playing this! I also own the Crest Climbers version.

item.name: Arcadia Quest
item.comment:
Really, really fun. Create a team, equip them with gear, and go out and hit things. Get new gear, go hit things harder. Awesome! The only really bad thing about the game is that it takes a while to set up, but it's no worse than Descent or any other map tile-based game.
Also own the Beyond the Grave expansion.

item.name: BANG! The Bullet!
item.comment: Fired from my collection by The Resistance (which has pretty much been fired by One Night Ultimate Werewolf).

item.name: Beasty Bar
item.comment: The icons on the cards aren't particularly helpful, but the game is easy to teach and understand, and you'll know what the cards all do after your first play. The artwork is really good as well, especially if you like skunk butts. Fun little game, and unlike anything else in my collection.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment:
Barely a game, and there are times when it is barely fun. With that being said, you really have no idea what will happen when you play this game, and are almost guaranteed to have a memorable experience when the haunt occurs.
It's like Resident Evil mixed with Scooby Doo, and I really enjoy it. It's the type of game that I'll keep in my collection even though it rarely makes it to the table. Just playing it once every Halloween would be enough for me!
EDIT: Sold my copy, although a friend owns it so I still get to play!

item.name: Biblios
item.comment:
Fast, nice components, easy to teach, plays great with 2 players. A lot of fun in a small, book-shaped package.
EDIT: Removed from my collection due to lack of plays. Biblios is a good game, but hard to get excited about playing.

item.name: The Big Idea
item.comment:
Great with a creative group, and even people who don't think they are creative can get into this one in no time.
My advice is to slip a note-card into the box so you can write down particularly memorable combinations.
EDIT: Fired from my collection by "But Wait, There's More!"

item.name: Black Fleet
item.comment: Awesome components (I love putting cubes in the little ships) and just a great overall game. The variable player powers really add a lot, as they allow you to break the game's rules in some way. It's always really fun to see what other players are unlocking, and while the game can get kind of mean when your ships start being sunk, you get them all back the very next turn. Highly recommend this one.
item.wishlistcomment: I love that this game has a "take-that" feel without hurting anyone's feelings. The components are incredible.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: I love this game. I love how aggressive it can get without anyone really having their feelings hurt. I love all the wheeling and dealing. I love saying the word "beans" 500 times in one game. Looooooove it!

item.name: The Bottle Imp
item.comment: Fun, but fired from my collection by Chronicle.

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: Bruges isn't a bad game, but the mechanics are so far removed from the theme that it's hard to feel invested at all in what you're doing. Games like that don't have a place in my collection!

item.name: But Wait, There's More!
item.comment: Fired The Big Idea from my collection, and can be downright hilarious when played with the right people. A bad group will make this an unbearable game, though; you've got to play with people who can be creative on the fly.

item.name: Buzz It!
item.comment: Fun, simple party game.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Guns (second edition)
item.comment: Fun and funny. Not the type of game I want to play all the time, but it works great with big groups and is super simple to teach.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: I always stop one roll of the dice too late. Exists comfortably in my collection with another awesome push-your-luck game, Incan Gold.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity
item.comment:
I hate Apples to Apples, mostly because I feel like there is no way to catch up if you fall behind. In Cards Against Humanity this never feels like a problem, because so many of your card choices are awful and hilarious, and when you lose it's usually because someone else played something even funnier. Fun game if you've got the right group for it.
EDIT: Big problem with this game - playing it too much, or letting a session go for too long. If people stop giggling at the cards, it's time to play the haiku card and move on! Fell way down in my rankings due to overplaying, and I'm not really sure I ever need to play it again.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity: Third Expansion
item.comment: Out of all the expansions, I think this one is my favorite.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: When I play Castles of Burgundy, I can tell it's a really well-designed game, but it still feels like it's missing something (fun, perhaps). It's really ugly-looking, and by the time I finish a game of it, I just feel...nothing. I enjoy the gameplay well enough I guess, but I'd just rather play something a little more exciting. Really surprised that it is rated as highly as it is on BGG.

item.name: Catan
item.comment:
Fun game at first, but it always drags by the end. I'd sell it if my wife didn't love it so much.
I also own the 5-6 player expansion.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment:
Conflicted. Agricola is one of my top 10 games of all time, and I think Caverna might be better, but....not in my top 10? I prefer the theme and tension of Agricola, but I am the only one of my game group who feels this way.
Great game, but...eh. It just doesn't have the same magic as Agricola to me, even if it might be a better game overall.

item.name: Chronicle
item.comment: Great artwork, and I enjoy that each round has a different "goal" that changes the mechanics of the game (sometimes you want to win tricks, sometimes you don't).

item.name: Click Clack Lumberjack
item.comment: Simple fun, with lots of laughs. Setup is a little long for a game that can be ended in one mighty swing of a plastic axe.

item.name: Concept
item.comment: Board game version of charades, kind of. It's really fun to try map out your thought process and lead other people to the correct guess. Not the type of game I want to play all the time, but I always enjoy myself when I do.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment:
I love how asymmetric this game is, but hate how the conflict between players makes the weenies in my game group dislike it. This one doesn't make it to my table nearly as much as I would like.
I also own ALL the expansions!

item.name: Coup
item.comment:
Even though I hate the art style (ESPECIALLY when compared with the original or some of the awesome international versions), the game just seemed like too good of a fit for my group. As a result, I backed the Kickstarter version that also came with the Reformation expansion.
My verdict? DISAPPOINTMENT. The game is fine, but very...bland. I'd rather play Mascarade or The Resistance every time.

item.name: Crows
item.comment: Good little game, feels like solving a puzzle when you play it. It's cheap, fast, and fun. Unfortunately, it wasn't getting played, so it flew out of my collection to shinier pastures.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment: I took advantage of the game being sold out and sold my copy, and haven't felt the need to replace it. Not a bad game by any means, but the game always felt a little anticlimactic to me.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment:
I love Descent as a replacement for traditional pen and paper adventures. It's a lot easier to get right into the business of running a campaign for those of us without a lot of spare time.
I'm a terrible Overlord, but that makes me a GREAT Overlord, because I am most concerned in making sure everyone is having fun, myself included. If you just try to crush the heroes, you might end up winning, but you might also end up with nobody to play Descent with.
I also own all of the base-game lieutenant packs, as well as the Shadow of Nerekhall, Lair of the Wyrm, Trollfens, and Manor of Ravens expansions.

item.name: Diamonds
item.comment: Trick-taking game that even people in my group who hate trick-taking games enjoy. Easy to learn, fun and fast to play, and I looooove playing around with the gems.

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: Easy to learn, fast to play, and I love the hidden roles everyone has. My favorite part of the game is definitely looking at the actions of the other players and trying to figure out what they are working towards. Everyone tries to team up on the player who might be winning, while also trying to screw everyone else over and advance their own agendas. As an added bonus, the artwork in the game really makes me want to read more of the Discworld books!

item.name: Divinare
item.comment: When you first play this game you will not understand how you are ever supposed to get a prediction right. It all comes together quickly, however, and the amazing components and short playtime make this one a keeper.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment:
The very first turn I ever played in Dixit resulted in everyone playing a card that perfectly matched the story. I have been hooked ever since, although the cards in the expansions are not quite as good as those in the original game.
I also own the Odyssey and Quest expansions.

item.name: Dixit Odyssey
item.comment: More playing pieces are nice (although they can't be turned into a squirrel anymore), but the pegboards for voting are awful.

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: More cards, although the pictures just aren't as evocative as the ones in the base game.

item.name: Drako
item.comment: Fast, fun 2-player game with awesome components.

item.name: Dungeon Petz
item.comment: I really like Dungeon Petz, but there are a ton of components and the game can feel very fiddly at times. Despite having a ton of things going on at once, the rules always justify what is happening (and the rulebook is hilarious). Fun game, which I think might deserve a higher rating if I can get the same group of people to play it a few times.
item.wishlistcomment: I like the theme of Dungeon Lords better, but the reviews of Petz make me think I'd like it more in terms of gameplay. Some of the reviews make it seem like it's too complicated for its own good, but I like that it can be played with two players and is apparently pretty awesome once you get the rules down.

item.name: Dutch Blitz
item.comment: A vonderful goot family card game. My wife loves this one.

item.name: Elk Fest
item.comment: Fun and silly disk-flicking game, with awesome wooden moose meeples.

item.name: Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Duel at Mt. Skullzfyre
item.comment:
Not the best game in the world, but it plays somewhat fast (although it can definitely drag at times), is funny, and is worth buying just for the artwork.
I don't think we ever finish the game once we start. We'll just play a few rounds and move on to something else. As a result, I sold this one off.

item.name: Escape from the Aliens in Outer Space
item.comment:
Out of all the games I own, this is one of the most atmospheric, tense, and memorable. So tense that my wife won't play it due to how stressed out she gets. Everyone wants to see everyone else's maps at the end and discuss how the game played out.
All of this from a small box consisting of some cards, paper maps, and a few pencils. Awesome. The only thing keeping me from ranking it higher is that it has player elimination, which I hate.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment:
We are TERRIBLE at this game!!! There is a 1 in 6 chance of rolling a black mask, which locks one of your dice up, and we roll them constantly. It can be rather frustrating.
All the same, Escape is fast and a lot of fun.
I also own the Illusions expansion. You can fit everything from the base game in the Illusions box with room to spare, which is awesome!
item.wishlistcomment: Hearing great things - sounds like a chaotically fun time.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: Like For Sale, but much more randomness, and therefore a lot more humor. I definitely prefer For Sale, but Felix is a fun game to play from time to time and definitely creates more memorable moments.

item.name: Finca
item.comment: The theme is completely pasted on, but I still found the idea of delivering fruit around an island to be very relaxing. I like this game a lot, especially with two players. It's still fun with more, but two is the best.

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment: Great game, as long as everyone plays similarly. Analysis paralysis could make this game AWFUL; you have to be able to quickly find a decent move and then just make it. Despite a lot of different strategies to take, all of our scores usually end up pretty similar -- this is a sign of great design to me! Beautiful components as well!

item.name: Fleet
item.comment: Fun game with cool artwork and components, but just didn't make a splash in my group.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Simple, fast, awesome. A great game to play pretty much anywhere and with anyone.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment:
While the game is still fun, the theme has really suffered since it switched to Friday the 13th from Poison. In Poison, the game made more sense; you were filling cauldrons with ingredients, trying not to get them to boil over, and avoiding poison. In Friday the 13th, you are just avoiding too many ladders and black cats.
It's a minor quibble, but the new theme just doesn't work as well, and turned me off my plans of purchasing the game.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: Half of my game groups loves it, the other half hates it. Building a spaceship is definitely more fun than seeing all of the terrible things that happen to it. Tons of little pieces to deal with during the game. Despite these issues, I'm still a fan. I don't want to play it all the time, but I definitely plan on holding on to it.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment:
Takes a long time to play. Way too many little rule details. Definitely a hard game to get to the table. Despite all those things, it's FUN. The game is completely worth it for those moments when everyone flips over their order tokens and you find out just how much you are going to be helped/screwed.
EDIT: Fun game, but too long to get played very often. Sold my copy.

item.name: Ghost Blitz
item.comment: This is a simple game, so why does my brain hurt so much?

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: Almost sold this one because I had heard it was very similar to Race for the Galaxy, which I already own. Sooooo happy I kept it. Great game, and not at all hard to pick up once you figure out the rules. I prefer RftG for 2-player games, and GtR for everything else.

item.name: Good Cop Bad Cop
item.comment:
Fun game that I think will eventually fire The Resistance in my collection. I like that you don't have to lie and bluff (that much), which makes The Resistance really hard for some players.
I also own the Bombers and Traitors expansion.

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: It's fun enough, and there's nothing else like it in my collection, but find myself never wanting to play it either.

item.name: Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: Fun little game, but the looooooooooooooong setup time is a pain in the butt and keeps this one from hitting the table more often.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: Bug chess! Lots of fun, easy to learn, and fast to play. I love that I can tell how crappy I am at the game, which really makes me want to improve and keep playing!

item.name: Incan Gold
item.comment: Great press-your-luck game. Exists happily alongside Can't Stop in my collection.
item.wishlistcomment: Fun, fast, and supports lots of players. Sounds like a winner to me!

item.name: Inkognito
item.comment: Fun hidden roles game, with the biggest downside being that you really need 4 players, and 4 players only, to have a good time. Awesome components in this one as well.
item.wishlistcomment: Played the Ares Games version at Gen Con 2013. Seems right up my alley, and has beautiful components. My wife likes it too!

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: Great little two-player game. Fast, easy to learn, fun.

item.name: Jamaica
item.comment: Fast, easy to teach, and absolutely gorgeous to look at. The gameplay is pretty shallow, but overall, Jamaica doesn't overstay its welcome.
item.wishlistcomment: A lot of people seem to think it's too light, but the game looks really fun and the components are gorgeous. Leaning towards getting this one (if I can ever find it). Might fall off the list if I get another racing game in the meantime.

item.name: Jungle Speed
item.comment: So easy to teach, and so much fun. I love how much this game gets everyone at the table laughing.

item.name: K2
item.comment:
Love this game. Thematic, great artwork, and creates memorable moments.
The first time we played, my wife raced to the top of the mountain with me close on her heels, only to get stuck at the summit during bad weather. By the time her climber finally succumbed to the worsening conditions, my own climber, who had been waiting out the storm right below the summit, was in such bad shape he died the next turn (RIP Sherpa Bob). Our friend, who had been waiting further down the mountain, then leisurely cruised to victory. Great first impression for a great game.
I also own the Broad Peak expansion.

item.name: King of New York
item.comment:
Fired King of Tokyo from my collection. I like that KoNY gives the players more to do if they aren't in the main point-getting parts of the city (Tokyo/Manhattan). I'll of course keep KoT, so I can keep playing as Cyber Bunny!
EDIT: Not sure if I'll ever play this one with more than 4. At higher player counts, the game drags and it's really hard to see anything on the board.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment:
I have a blast with King of Tokyo every single time I play it. The artwork in the game is awesome, it plays quickly, and I've never once felt bored. Great game. The only knock against it is that it has player elimination, although the game usually doesn't last much longer once monsters start dying off.
I highly recommend playing with the variant found here:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/821635/thedackers-double-dose-of-energy-variant
I also own the Power Up and Halloween expansions.
EDIT: Definitely fired from my collection by King of New York. I like that KoNY gives the players more to do if they aren't in the main point-getting parts of the city (Tokyo/Manhattan). I'll of course keep KoT, so I can keep playing as Cyber Bunny!

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment:
This game is kind of boring, but it's also very relaxing and has more strategy to it than it seems at first. I like it more than I am admitting here.
More importantly, my wife really likes it.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment:
Great artwork, fun dice-based gameplay, and plenty of different ways to go about trying to win. I don't think I'd like it nearly as much if I didn't also play with the To Forge a Realm expansion, though -- the variety it adds is well worth it.
EDIT: Sold my copy. It's a great game, but I feel like I saw everything the game had to show me, and my plays started to feel very "samey" after a while.

item.name: Kingsburg: To Forge a Realm
item.comment:
Completely worth it to add variety to Kingsburg in the form of more/new buildings, along with some other ways to change the gameplay.
I'd go as far to say that Kingsburg isn't worth playing without the new building boards this expansion adds.

item.name: Klunker
item.comment: Nothing amazing, but still fun. Filler card game.

item.name: Last Will
item.comment: I love the theme of the game, and it's one of my favorite worker placements. Taking your dog and horse to the theater has never been so much fun! Between this and Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy, I think I like Last Will more, while my wife is the opposite.
item.wishlistcomment:
I had this game off my wishlist for a while, but can't remember why. I keep hearing great things about it and the theme looks like a ton of fun, so it's back on the list again!
My biggest reservation is that I don't really need another worker placement game, so I put this one at "Thinking About It" for now.

item.name: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy
item.comment:
I really enjoy this one. We often find that our families start taking on certain themes as we play (lots of craftsmen, lost of one particular nationality, etc.) due to the goals we are trying to achieve, which adds a nice little layer of storytelling to the game. It plays a little differently than other worker placement games I own, and I'm happy to have it in my collection.
Unfortunately, the game doesn't come with one of the necessary components: a huge honking table. Also unfortunately, the cards used for currency in the game STINK. There just aren't enough, and they get messy as the game progresses. I use the coins from Tuscany as a replacement.
item.wishlistcomment: The Dice Tower review sold me on this one. I've been hearing lots of good things!

item.name: Letters from Whitechapel
item.comment:
Great hidden movement game, but takes a loooooong time to play (usually over 2 hours for us), and can get pretty frustrating for the investigators if they can't find any clues. Still, if you like this style of game, Letters from Whitechapel is a winner.
EDIT: Fired from my collection by Fury of Dracula.
item.wishlistcomment: We loooooove hidden movement games like Nuns on the Run and Escape from the Aliens in Outer Space. My wife is freaked out by Escape and Nuns on the Run works best with lots of players, so this one looks like a winner.

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment:
One of my all-time favorites. Easy to teach and learn, plays quickly, and always has the potential for big surprises and laughs. It has player elimination, but you're never out for that long.
I own the Perudo version, with its awesome colorful dice!

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment: So simple, and so much fun. My favorite part of this game is how much everyone accuses the other players of cheating!

item.name: Lords of Vegas
item.comment: Fun game, but just too long for what it was. Fired from my collection by its predecessor, Chinatown.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Fast, simple to teach, and a lot of fun. The worst thing about it is that the artwork is super boring, so I ended up picking up the Kanai Factory edition with the original art (although I prefer the new version's Contessa to the original's Minister -- the Contessa adds a layer of bluffing to the game, while the Minister adds more risk).

item.name: Magical Athlete
item.comment:
The combination of characters can lead to some really funny races. My favorite part of this game is that you usually don't feel too bad when you lose because the race itself was so ridiculous.
The only real issue with the game (despite the fact that it has the UGLIEST board ever) is that it lasts a little too long.

item.name: Marrying Mr. Darcy
item.comment: My wife loves the source material, and I love my wife, so I was happy to add this one to my collection. It's a mechanically simple game, but I actually really like it. The artwork is good, some of the cards are really funny, and while I'm never going to suggest it, I'm always happy to play it.

item.name: Martian Dice
item.comment: Fun, easy, cheap. Plus the dice look awesome! Lots of fun to be had with this one when you don't have time for something bigger, although the game can take a surprisingly long time sometimes if the dice aren't going your way.

item.name: Mascarade
item.comment:
Lots of fun and laughs, and plays with a large group. Great game!
I also own the expansion.

item.name: Monikers
item.comment: Fired Time's Up from my collection. Fun party game, although I find some of the cards to be a little TOO obscure.

item.name: Morels
item.comment: Great two-player game. Nice artwork, and I love the hand-crafted foraging sticks and frying pans. When Two Lanterns Games shipped this one to me they even included a hand-written note. FAN FOR LIFE!

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment:
Really fun 2-player game. I definitely enjoy playing as Jack more than the investigator, although it's much harder to win.
I also own Mr. Jack in New York, as well as the Extension and Carriage expansions.

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment:
This game has a great theme and is really fun when the players get into it. I want to make cloth hoods in the colors of the game pieces to add to the experience!
One of the best things I can say about it is that when somebody correctly identifies the culprit, almost everyone else at the table was right on the verge of guessing it as well. Nobody ever feels like they were completely out of the game.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment:
My favorite things about Nexus Ops is how straightforward it is. Put your dudes on a map, move them around the map, and hit other people's dudes. Awesome.
Unfortunately, it's so straightforward that it's a little hard to get excited about playing. When you've got a good group together and just want to bash each other, though, Nexus Ops is gold.

item.name: Nuns on the Run
item.comment: Fun game and theme, but people really need to be paying attention the whole time and know all the rules. A player accidentally not realizing they are in line of sight can make things awfully difficult (and frustrating) for the abbess/prioress.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
item.comment: Almost immediately dissolves into absurdity, but the game is fun and funny. Don't take it too seriously and you'll have a great time.
item.wishlistcomment: My wife thinks it looks fun, and so do I. Shut Up & Sit Down sold me on this one.

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment:
Takes a few plays to get into, but holy crap is it fun once you do. The app is a must have, in my opinion.
Also own the Daybreak expansion.

item.name: Panic on Wall Street!
item.comment: This game is fun, fast, and LOUD. I'll happily play this one anytime it's suggested, and it works great with big groups.
item.wishlistcomment: Shut Up & Sit Down put this one on my radar. Looks like a lot of fun!

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment:
Awesome, awesome 2 player game. I love how simple it is, while also presenting a little puzzle to solve.
I replaced the button tokens in the game with real buttons, which makes the game more fiddly but adds a fun tactile experience.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment:
Do you love rolling a dice to make skill checks? Over and over and over and over and over? Do you wish a game was invented where that was pretty much the only thing you did?
Your wish has been granted.

item.name: Pictomania
item.comment: Fun, but a little fiddly for this type of game (which is kind of par for the course as far as a Vlaada game is concerned). Lots of little chits and cards to keep track of. All the same, trying to draw some of the harder words is a ton of fun, and the game can be super funny. Recommended, and I would pretty much always prefer this game to Telestrations.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Bought into the hype, which this game never really lived up to. It's not bad by any means -- it just wasn't a very good fit for my group.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
My wife ALWAYS wins this game. For some reason my planets producing nothing but minerals and knick-knacks don't lead me to victory.
The symbols and icons in the game are just as bad as most people say (I personally don't find them very intuitive), although you definitely get used to them after a while.

item.name: Rattus
item.comment:
I don't know what to make of this one. The components are awesome, it plays fast and is easy to teach, and the theme is right up my alley. The problem is, well...it's kind of bland. I don't want to sell it, but I don't really ever play it either, which is a problem because I really feel like this one deserves more plays than I have given it so far.
I also own the Pied Piper expansion.
EDIT: Sold from my collection due to lack of plays.

item.name: Rattus: Pied Piper
item.comment: I already think Rattus is kind of boring, and would feel even more strongly about that if it weren't for the new characters this expansion adds.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment:
This game has been somewhat fired from my collection by One Night Werewolf, but I still enjoy playing it from time to time. My students love love LOVE it too.
I also own the Hidden Agenda expansion, which lets me combine the awesome extra roles from Avalon with the artwork and theme from the original Resistance, which I much prefer.

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment:
The new role cards make a HUGE and positive difference in the game. I can't see myself ever wanting to play the original again, even though I prefer its art.
EDIT: Replaced by the new edition of Resistance, along with the Hidden Agenda expansion. Better art + Avalon roles!

item.name: Rhino Hero
item.comment: This game is a lot of fun for adults, and can be surprisingly tense as the tower gets bigger!

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment:
Fun and chaotic. The components are pretty crummy; I wish the boards were thicker!
EDIT: Maybe a little too chaotic. Also, the game always felt liked it dragged on and on, even on smaller maps.
item.wishlistcomment: Seems fun and chaotic, lots of people can play at once, and my wife loves robots. Looks like a winner!

item.name: Rococo
item.comment: Blech. Point salad scoring, and just way too much going on for not a lot of payoff.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment:
Surprisingly blah. The game can be really fun and funny, but I find that it's mostly just kind of boring. Most of the time my group only tries to sneak contraband through once or twice a game, so the sheriff just keeps getting burned over and over again by opening bags. If the sheriff tries to take their time questioning people, the game bogs down (EDIT: the app helps a lot with timing the sheriff, as well as helping with the tedious scoring!).
Great idea, just not as fun as I was hoping. A hit with my group, however.
EDIT: Upgraded my rating based off some info I read here at BGG. It basically said that as a bluffing game, Sheriff is pretty crappy. As a NEGOTIATION game, however, it shines. If you play to what the Sheriff is collecting (you see that he has a lot of apples, so you slip a few in your bag and offer him the choice of a card if he lets you through), the game becomes a LOT more fun and the amount of contraband trying to be brought in skyrockets, making all aspects of the game better.

item.name: Skittykitts
item.comment: I could not believe how much fun I had playing this as a 2 player game. Super chaotic (and fun!) with more than 2.

item.name: Skull
item.comment: I have both the Black and Red versions. Fun and fast bluffing game. Nobody in my group ever wants to play it!

item.name: Sleuth
item.comment: A deduction game boiled down to its most simple form. Fun to play when we don't have time for a longer deduction game, although definitely not as much of a filler game as it first seemed.
item.wishlistcomment: Small game, which I love (maybe too much, they are kind of overflowing out of my shelves), and I've heard it's one the best deduction games out there. I like the genre, but the games can be very hit or miss. This one looks like a hit.

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
One of the first "real" board games I ever played. Fast, fun, and the many race-power combinations ensure that every game feels different. I've thought about selling it and the expansions a few times, but I just can't bring myself to part with it, even though I've moved on to other games at this point.
I also own the Cursed, Be Not Afraid, Grand Dames, and Tales and Legends expansions.

item.name: Small World: Be Not Afraid...
item.comment: New races and powers = good.

item.name: Small World: Cursed!
item.comment: New races and powers = good.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
item.comment: New races + powers = good. Definitely the least vital of all the expansions, though. Probably wouldn't buy it again if I got a do-over.

item.name: Small World: Tales and Legends
item.comment: Adds a bit of life to the game in the form of random events that happen each turn. It's not an expansion I always want to include, but it's almost always a lot of fun to do so.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game
item.comment:
Fun game, but can be hard to figure out where to go once you own a core set. I recommend just getting whatever looks fun to you and going from there!
I also own the X-Wing, Y-Wing, Milennium Falcon, Tie Bomber, and HWK-290 expansions.
EDIT: Sold my collection after it sat for awhile collecting dust.

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment:
Anyone who compares this game to SimCity is doing it a disservice. Suburbia is fun, but the only thing it shares with SimCity is a similar theme. The gameplay is all about finding good combos with tiles and setting yourself up for success later in the game, and while it is certainly fun, a little more player interaction (outside of blocking each other from taking tiles and the occasional bonus from someone else's suburb) would be welcome.
A solid 7.5. Good, but not quite great.
item.wishlistcomment: Going by appearance alone, this game looks sooooo boring. Everything I've read about it, however, makes it seem incredible. SimCity in game form? AMAZING.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Alliances Master Set
item.comment: Adds more variety to an already awesome game.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment:
Amazing 2-player game. I love how almost every match ends in some dramatic way. The different factions all feel really different from one another. I have considered selling this game and just playing on the app, but it's definitely a game worth keeping around (even though the box is huge).
I also own all the faction decks and Second Summoner decks. This is one of the few games I will pretty much blindly buy any expansion for, with the exception of the reinforcement decks (don't really see the need to change things up with them!).

item.name: Super Motherload
item.comment:
Not the Trains-killer I was hoping for, but still a really good game. I love the art style, and the game flows well and quickly.
My biggest issue with the game is that the deck-building aspect is pretty unsatisfying. Yes, the cards you add to your deck will make big, immediate improvements, but since the artwork on the new cards is the same as the old, it doesn't feel "special" when you upgrade a pilot.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment:
This game can get mean really fast, but it never feels particularly personal, and it's really easy to get revenge. Lots of fun, although watch out for those whose feelings get hurt easily. For some reason, they will have a hard time getting over the sharks and sea monsters you direct to eat their survivors.
I also own the 5-6 player and Giant Squid expansions.

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: Amazing components. It's not the most deeply strategic game in the world, but it's fun, easy to learn, and plays quickly.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: I knew this game was for me from the very first time I played it. That first play resulted in so many funny and memorable moments, my favorite of which was definitely when my brother-in-law chose the option to beat a dying hunchback (he later chose to just rob him instead), followed closely my wife getting hit in the face with a rock and losing her "seductive" character trait.
item.wishlistcomment: Not sure what to make of this one. The story element really appeals to me and I think my friends would like it, but some review have given me pause. Seems like people love it or hate it (I'm leaning towards the love side, myself).

item.name: Telestrations
item.comment: This game has made me laugh so hard I cried, but I definitely played it too many times in a short amount of time. It has gotten to the point where I only want to play it every now and then, but it never disappoints.

item.name: Them's Fightin' Words!
item.comment: A funny, simple game where you take turns insulting each other, only you have to say all the insults that came before, you yellow-bellied, no-good, son-of-a biscuit!

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment:
The game that really got me into board gaming. I still find it incredibly fun despite playing the crap out of it.
I also own the USA 1910 expansion.

item.name: Time's Up! Title Recall!
item.comment:
Supports a lot of players and can be a lot of fun.
EDIT: Fired from my collection by Monikers.

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: Some of the best components in any game I own. The game is easy to learn, plays fast, and is a great gateway game. The gameplay is like nothing else in my collection.

item.name: Tokyo Train
item.comment: Loco Motive (formerly Tokyo Train) is not a game you're going to play all the time, but those few times you do play are going to be a blast. It's fast, fun, and incredibly funny. The BGG scale makes me want to give it a 6, but the amount of fun I have with it makes me want to give it an 8. I compromised with a 7!

item.name: Trains
item.comment:
This game looks soooo boring, and truth be told, it IS boring. It's also very well-made, plays fast, and having a board is a definite improvement on the deck-building formula.
Despite being a very good game, however, I have a hard time getting past the boring board, boring card artwork, and boring theme. I'm happy to have it in my collection, and I always enjoy the times I play it, but it's a hard game to get super excited about playing.
item.wishlistcomment: I like Dominion a lot. It's easy to teach, intuitive, and fast. I have heard Trains described as an improved version of the Dominion-style deck builder, but would the added complexity make the game less accessible?

item.name: Trollhalla
item.comment:
Fun, easy to learn, and my wife loves it. Sea-faring trolls plundering islands is an underused theme in board gaming!
EDIT: Unfortunately, I feel like Trollhalla might have shown us all it has to offer. It's a great little game, but doesn't have a lot of staying power.
item.wishlistcomment: Looks like a blast! Just found out about this one recently and wished I had heard of it sooner.

item.name: Viticulture
item.comment:
A lot of fun, and the mechanic of only having certain actions available during certain phases of the game helps differentiate it from other worker placements in my collection. I find myself always wanting to play it, although it's not the most popular game with everyone in my group. I also find myself always wanting a glass of wine while playing, and I'm more of a beer guy myself.
I also own the Tuscany expansion, with its sweet sweet metal coins. The extra modules it adds to the game will make it so you never go back to the base game again.

item.name: Witness
item.comment: I can't see myself ever owning another game quite like this one. Solving games by playing a variation of telephone sounds INCREDIBLY TERRIBLE, but it is so much fun. There are times I have laughed so much trying to convey the facts I knew to another player that I started forgetting super important details, which just made me crack up even more. I am not familiar with the source material, but love the artwork. Big fan of this one.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: The best part about this game is that it's a trivia game in which you can know practically nothing about trivia and still win. It's been a hit every single time it's made it to the table.

item.name: Wiz-War (eighth edition)
item.comment:
Love love love love love this game.
I definitely recommend implementing ALL of the rule changes found here:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/803845/why-the-new-version-seems-unfun-and-my-suggestions/page/1
The game becomes much more about running around and casting fun spells, rather than worrying about counter-spells and racing to see who gets the treasures back to their base first.
I also own the Malefic Curses and Bestial Forces expansions.

item.name: Wiz-War: Malefic Curses
item.comment: Perfect expansion. Inexpensive, everything fits in the original game box, and adds more fun stuff to a game already loaded with fun stuff.
item.wishlistcomment: Love Wiz War, and can't wait to add more to the game.

item.name: Yetisburg: Titanic Battles in History, Vol. 1
item.comment:
On our first play, my wife got stuck with a hand of five cards that had no match on the battlefield. She then passed for the last half of the game while I proceeded to shoot all my own soldiers, miss hitting her soldiers, and run out of cards to draw, thus losing.
I love the theme and artwork of this game, but man, I feel like our first game could not have been more of a stinker. It's a shame when one play makes me already think of house rules that could salvage things.
